title: I am filing bankruptcy and my mom is giving me a truck since I will be losing our car?
question: I am filing chapter 7 bankruptcy in CA and my mom is giving me my dads truck (passed away a couple months ago) the truck is worth 40k but it will be given as a gift. Can they take it from me?
answers:
Yes, I also agree with the other attorneys that you should consult with a bankruptcy attorney. More than that, you should HIRE a quality bankruptcy attorney.

A "free consultation" will only get you so much information. Attorneys are not there to spend money for their offices and employees only to give you their services for free. Therefore, they are NOT going to tell you everything to be your own attorney. An attorney may tell you about the top of the iceberg. However, it is what was below the waterline that sank the Titanic.

I have seen absolute disasters from people who thought that they get everything for free from those attorneys and then filed their own bankruptcy cases. Here is a situation that could have cost you the loss of a $20,000 vehicle to save some attorney’s fees. And that is just one thing. Lord knows what others are out there that you would never have a clue about.

I just had a case where people had a "free consultation" with me. It was a complicated case as to planning to deal with things that they had that were not "exempt" meaning it was something a trustee could take away. I had solutions. However, they had some cheap "legal insurance" through their employer or their union. No experienced attorney is going to do bankruptcy based on what these insurance policies will pay.

They ended up using it and saved about $1,500 in out of pocket fees. The attorney failed to understand things that an attorney with several decades experience would have known. As a result, they found themselves losing over $20,000.

They came back to me. I could not help myself and pointed out that they saved $1,500 off my fees. They wanted me to substitute into their case in place of the attorney that was such a deal. I told them they would have to pay me the whole fee I had quoted PLUS $500 more because I was now having to clean up the mess their case now was. In addition, I told them that I could only fix about $12,000 of the problems. They were still going to lose about $8,000 to the Bankruptcy Trustee. No one was happy... except the bankruptcy trustee and the creditors.

I recommend that you check and see if you can find an attorney that is a California State Bar Certified Bankruptcy Law Specialist. Warning, many attorneys say that they "specialize in bankruptcy." That does not mean they are a state bar CERTIFIED bankruptcy law specialist. You can find out who is by going to the California State Bar website.

You can cross over to see what they have as an Avvo.com 10.0 Rating. There are enough attorneys in Sacramento with a 10.0 Avvo rating that there is no reason to spend time and effort on attorneys with a lower Avvo rating.

Two things you never want to do is brain surgery on yourself and representing yourself as your own lawyer. Neither turn out well.

There is an old saying that "a person who represents themselves has a fool for a client and a fool for an attorney."

I agree with my esteemed colleagues 100%. Do your BK then receive the truck from your mom. You should be in the clear if you do things in that sequence. Remember, BK is not a DIY project consisting of simply checking boxes on forms you find on-line. Find/consult/hire an Avvo BK lawyer in your area by using the "Find a Lawyer" feature. Make a list consisting of several BK lawyers having many 5 star reviews from satisfied clients. If you don't get a prompt call back, go on to the next one on your list. Some offer a free consultation by phone or in person. Take them up on it.

I agree with Attorney Caldwell. That is simple law..which means you have NOT done the one thing you must do: see and employ an experienced Bankruptcy attorney now. And other facts and issues can affect your case also so I will point out some so you understand WHY you must employ an attorney to avoid such a common and other mistakes persons without an attorney commit all the time.

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

File your bankruptcy. Drive your current car until they repo it. Get your discharge, then have mom give you your father's truck. If it is titled in your name prior to filing the trustee may be able to take it because the value of the truck exceeds what can be exempted under most states laws, including California's.
